# 开始新功能分支
git checkout -b feature/<feature name> develop

# 完成功能并合并回 develop 分支
git checkout develop

git branch -d feature/<feature name>

docs.title: Scene and Animations
docs.text:
• ThreeDScene: Always use the ThreeDScene class when creating 3D animations. It provides essential methods for working with 3D objects and camera control.
  • Basic methods:
    • self.add()
    • self.play(..., run_time=NUM) (I think for every animation, we can control its duration, but I haven't verify it yet)
    • self.wait()
%%manim -qm Example
class Example(ThreeDScene):
def construct(self):
pass

docs.title: Axes
docs.text:
• Always use the ThreeAxes(**axes_config) class, define the range of the axes by yourself by changing the values in x_range, y_range and z_range
  • You can use add_coordinate() to mark the numbers on the axe
  • Add labels at the end of the axes: x_label = Tex("$x$").next_to(axes.x_axis.get_end(), RIGHT, buff=0.2)

docs.title: Camera
docs.text:
• Explication:
  • Initialisation: set_camera_orientation(phi=None, theta=None, gamma=None, zoom=None, focal_distance=None, frame_center=None, **kwargs) (I actually never use gamma, conversely, I found distance extremely useful. See examples below)
  • Begin continuous camera rotation around the scene: begin_ambient_camera_rotation(rate=0.02, about='theta')
    • This method begins an ambient rotation of the camera about the Z_AXIS, in the anticlockwise direction
    • PARAMETERS
      • rate (float) – The rate at which the camera should rotate about the Z_AXIS. Negative rate means clockwise rotation.
      • about (str) – one of 3 options: [“theta”, “phi”, “gamma”]. defaults to theta.
  • Stop the continuous camera rotation: stop_ambient_camera_rotation()
  • Move the camera to a new position: move_camera(*args, **kwargs)
  • Default position
%%manim -qm Example
class Example(ThreeDScene):
def construct(self):
axes_config = {
"x_range": [-5, 5],
"y_range": [-5, 5],
"z_range": [-5, 5],
}
axes = ThreeDAxes(**axes_config).add_coordinates()
self.add(axes)
# Labels for x, y, and z axes
x_label = Tex("$x$").next_to(axes.x_axis.get_end(), RIGHT, buff=0.2)
y_label = Tex("$y$").next_to(axes.y_axis.get_end(), UP, buff=0.2)
z_label = Tex("$z$").next_to(axes.z_axis.get_end(), UP, buff=0.2)
self.add(x_label, y_label, z_label)
self.wait(3)
  • An ideal observation place
%%manim -qm Example
class Example(ThreeDScene):
def construct(self):
axes_config = {
"x_range": [-5, 5],
"y_range": [-5, 5],
"z_range": [-5, 5],
}
axes = ThreeDAxes(**axes_config).add_coordinates()
self.set_camera_orientation(phi=80*DEGREES,
theta=-40*DEGREES,
distance=6)
self.add(axes)
self.begin_ambient_camera_rotation(rate=0.9)
self.wait(3)
  • An example of transformation from 2D to 3D
%%manim -qm Example
class Example(ThreeDScene):
def construct(self):
axes_config = {
"x_range": [-5, 5],
"y_range": [-5, 5],
"z_range": [-5, 5],
}
axes = ThreeDAxes(**axes_config)
curve = ParametricFunction(lambda t: np.array([
np.cos(t), np.sin(3*t), np.cos(5*t)
]), color=YELLOW, t_range=(-5, 5))
self.add(axes, curve)
self.move_camera(phi=60*DEGREES, run_time=3)
self.begin_ambient_camera_rotation(rate=0.9)
self.wait(3)

docs.title: Text
docs.text:
• Use Text() class to create normal text informations.
  • Use Tex() class to create, use $$ when typing math equations and symbols !
  • Use scale to define its size.
  • Use rotate to change its orientation.

  • Changing the position:

    • shift and move_to, such as text.shift(LEFT*2 + UP*4)
    • next_to, such as text.next_to(circle, RIGHT, buff=0.5)

  • Important : There are two ways that the text appear, the first example shows that the text inclining with the camera, while the second example shows the text as if it is separated from the scene.

%%manim -qm Example
# Example 1 : Text oriented with the camera
class Example(ThreeDScene):
def construct(self):
text3d = Tex("Hello World!$2+3=5 \sum$").scale(2)
text3d.rotate(PI/2, axis=RIGHT)
self.set_camera_orientation(phi=80*DEGREES,
theta=-40*DEGREES,
distance=6)
self.play(Write(text3d))
self.wait()

%%manim -qm Example
from manim import *
# Example 2 : Text not oriented with the camera
class Example(ThreeDScene):
def construct(self):
text = Tex("Hello World!").scale(2)
text.shift(LEFT*2 + UP*3)
self.set_camera_orientation(phi=70 * DEGREES, theta=-60 * DEGREES)
# Add text to a 2D overlay, so it stays in front of the camera without any inclination
self.add_fixed_in_frame_mobjects(text)
self.play(Write(text)) # Without this line, it will appear directly.
self.wait()

docs.title: Transformations
docs.text:
Apply various transformations to your 3D objects using methods.

Manim can apply various transformations to 3D objects just as it does for 2D objects. Common transformations like translation, scaling, and rotation can be applied to 3D objects using methods like .animate syntax for animations and ... - move_to(), - scale(), - rotate()

%%manim -qm Example
class Example(ThreeDScene):
def construct(self):
axes = ThreeDAxes()
cube = Cube(color=YELLOW).scale(0.5).shift(LEFT)
sphere = Sphere(radius=0.5, resolution=(30, 30)).shift(RIGHT)
self.set_camera_orientation(phi=75 * DEGREES, theta=-45 * DEGREES, distance=8)
# Adding 3D objects to the scene
self.play(FadeIn(axes), FadeIn(cube), FadeIn(sphere))
self.wait()
# Translation
self.play(
cube.animate.shift(2 * UP + 2 * OUT),
sphere.animate.shift(2 * DOWN + 2 * IN),
)
self.wait()
# Scaling
self.play(
cube.animate.scale(2),
sphere.animate.scale(1.5),
)
self.wait()
# Rotation
self.play(
Rotate(cube, angle=PI, axis=RIGHT),
Rotate(sphere, angle=PI, axis=UP),
)
self.wait()

docs.title: Primitives
docs.text:
Manim has built-in 3D primitives like Sphere, Cone, Cylinder, Box, Torus, and Arrow3D. You can use these to create more complex 3D objects.

%%manim -qm Example
class Example(ThreeDScene):
def construct(self):
sphere = Sphere(radius=1, resolution=(30, 30))
cone = Cone(base_radius=1, height=2, direction=OUT)
cone.shift(LEFT*6 + UP*15)
self.set_camera_orientation(phi=80*DEGREES,
theta=-40*DEGREES,
distance=6)
self.add(sphere, cone)
self.play(ApplyMethod(sphere.move_to, np.array([3, -2, 1])))
self.wait()

docs.title: Curves and Paths
docs.text:
• ParametricFunction is a class in Manim that allows you to create curves or paths in 2D space using parametric equations. A parametric equation defines a curve by expressing the coordinates of each point on the curve as a function of a parameter, usually denoted by \(t\).

  • Define the curve: curve = ParametricFunction(curve_func, t_range=[t_min, t_max])

    • Here: curve_func could be: lambda t: np.array([func_1, func_2, func_3])

  • Transform between curves: Transform(curve1, curve2)

%%manim -qm Example
class Example(ThreeDScene):
def construct(self):
axes_config = {
"x_range": [-5, 5],
"y_range": [-5, 5],
"z_range": [-5, 5],
}
axes = ThreeDAxes(**axes_config)
self.set_camera_orientation(phi=80*DEGREES,
theta=-40*DEGREES,
distance=6)
self.begin_ambient_camera_rotation(rate=0.9)
self.add(axes)
curve = ParametricFunction(lambda t: np.array([
np.cos(t), np.sin(3*t), np.cos(5*t)
]), color=YELLOW, t_range=(-5, 5))
curve_new = ParametricFunction(lambda t: np.array([
np.cos(5*t), np.sin(t), np.cos(3*t)
]), color=BLUE, t_range=(-5, 5))
self.play(Write(curve), run_time=10)
self.play(Transform(curve, curve_new), run_time=5)
self.wait()

docs.title: Surfaces
docs.text:
In the context of Manim, ParametricSurface is a class that was available in earlier versions to create 3D surfaces by defining a parametric function. In the latest version of Manim, the ParametricSurface class has been replaced by the Surface class, which is used for the same purpose.

Parametric surfaces are 3D objects defined by parametric equations for the \(x\), \(y\), and \(z\) coordinates in terms of two parameters, usually denoted by \(u\) and \(v\). They can be used to create complex 3D objects like spheres, tori, or custom surfaces.

  • Define the surface: surface = Surface(surface_func, u_range=[u_min, u_max], v_range=[v_min, v_max], resolution=(NUM, NUM))
    • The resolution affects the time used to produce the video.
%%manim -qm Example
# Example of 3 surfaces
class Example(ThreeDScene):
def construct(self):
axes_config = {
"x_range": [-5, 5],
"y_range": [-5, 5],
"z_range": [-5, 5],
}
axes = ThreeDAxes(**axes_config)
self.set_camera_orientation(phi=80*DEGREES,
theta=-40*DEGREES,
distance=6)
self.begin_ambient_camera_rotation(rate=0.9)
self.add(axes)
bowl = Surface(
lambda u, v: np.array([
np.cos(v)*u, np.sin(v)*u, u**2
]), v_range=(-5, 5), resolution=(10, 32)
) # "resolution" affects the time used to produce the video!
HeatedSurface = Surface(
lambda u, v: np.array([
u, v, np.sin(v) + np.cos(v)
]), u_range=(-5, 5), v_range=(-5, 5), resolution=(15, 50)
)
PlaneSurface = Surface(
lambda u, v: np.array([
u, v, 2*u + 3*v -1
]), u_range=(-5, 5), resolution=(15, 50)
)
self.play(Write(bowl), run_time=3)
self.play(Write(HeatedSurface), run_time=5)
self.play(Write(PlaneSurface), run_time=3)
self.wait()

docs.title: Grouping
docs.text:
VGroup (short for "Vectorized Group") is a class in Manim that's used to group multiple Mobjects (short for "Mathematical Objects") together. This allows you to treat a collection of Mobjects as a single entity, making it easier to manipulate, transform, and animate them simultaneously.

Some common use cases forVGroup include:

  • Positioning: When you want to position multiple Mobjects relative to each other or in a specific arrangement, you can use a VGroup to move them together while preserving their relative positions.

  • Scaling and Rotation: When you want to scale or rotate multiple Mobjects as a unit, you can use a VGroup to apply the transformation to all of its child Mobjects.

  • Animation: When you want to animate multiple Mobjects simultaneously, you can use a VGroup to apply the animation to the entire group.

%%manim -qm VGroupExample
class VGroupExample(Scene):
def construct(self):
circle = Circle(color=RED)
square = Square(color=BLUE).scale(0.5)
triangle = Triangle(color=YELLOW).scale(0.5).next_to(square, RIGHT, buff=0.5)
# Create a VGroup containing the circle, square, and triangle
group = VGroup(circle, square, triangle)
# Position the group at the center of the screen
group.move_to(ORIGIN)
# Rotate the group by 45 degrees
group.rotate(45 * DEGREES)
self.play(FadeIn(group))
self.wait()
# Animate the group scaling up and down
self.play(group.animate.scale(1.5))
self.play(group.animate.scale(1/1.5))
self.wait()

docs.title: Essentials of Vim
docs.text:
• Use .+{deplacement}(such as j) to repeat your actions. No matter what repeating is a dull and meaningless work.
  • Regularly drop out from INSERT mode.

  • {Operator}+{Motion}, such as guiw, transforming a (inner) word to all lower-capped alphabets.

  • In order to allow . operation to repeat your actions, use the operator actions when it is possible, rather than entering the visual mode.

  • Use visual mode when it is hard to realize using normal operator motions, for example entering text in the same position of various lines.

  • Command line mode is suitable to do opertaions within a large scale or apart from a huge distance, such as :14t$. % is a little bit dangerous. ;)

  • Visual Mode -> command line mode, :normal

docs.title: Introductions
docs.text:
深度神经网络的安全问题已经成为一个主要关注点： - 如果NN模型无法识别路边的 “STOP” 标志，车辆继续行驶 - 公司经常使用图卷积网络（GCN）来决定其客户是否值得信任。

通过添加难以察觉的扰动攻击，深度学习模型被混淆，所有应用领域中普遍存在的例子提醒研究人员不要在安全关键的机器学习任务中直接采用DNN。

  • 对抗样本是机器学习模型的输入，攻击者故意设计这些输入以导致模型出错”。在图像分类领域，这些通用示例是故意合成的图像，看起来几乎与原始图像完全相同，但可能误导分类器提供错误的预测输出![[截屏2023-03-02 09.24.24.png]]

对策以抵抗对抗样本的攻击： - 梯度掩蔽：由于大多数攻击算法都基于分类器的梯度信息，因此掩蔽或模糊梯度将融合攻击机制 - 鲁棒性优化：这些研究显示了如何训练一个能够正确分类对抗性示例的鲁棒性高的分类器。 - 横向检测：这些方法试图在向深度学习模型反馈样本之前检查样本是良性还是对抗性的。它可以被视为防范对抗性例子的一种方法。这些方法提高了DNN对对抗性示例的抵抗力。

  • 黑盒攻击在黑盒攻击设置中，DNN模型的内部配置对对手不可用。对手只能输入数据并查询模型的输出。他们通常通过不断地向盒子中输入样本并观察输出来攻击模型，以揭示模型的输入-输出关系，并识别其弱点。与白盒攻击相比，黑盒攻击在应用程序中更实用，因为模型设计者通常出于专有原因而不开源其模型参数。
  • 半白（灰）盒攻击在半白盒或灰盒攻击设置中，黑客训练生成模型以在白盒设置中生成对抗性示例。一旦生成模型得到训练，攻击者就不再需要受害者模型，并且可以在黑盒背景下制作对抗性示例

docs.title: Brain-likeness: Brain Score
docs.text:
1. Brain-Score to evaluate any ANN on how brain-like it is – focusing on the parts of the brain that have been implicated in visual object recognition.

  2. Metrics:

    • The purpose of neural metrics is to establish how well internal representations of a source system match the internal representations in a target system.

  3. The global Brain-Score as a composite(mean) of neural V4 predictivity score, neural IT predictivity score, and behavioral I2n predictivity score:

    • Neural: Neural V4 predictivity score: V4 is mainly responsible for processing visual information of medium complexity. Compare the model's internal representation with neural data from V4.

    • Neural: Neural IT predictivity score: IT mainly responsible for processing complex visual information such as object recognition and scene analysis. Compare the model's internal representation with neural data from IT.

    • The neural dataset currently used in both neural benchmarks included in this version of BrainScore is comprised of neural responses to 2,560 naturalistic stimuli in 88 V4 neurons and 168 IT neurons.

    • Behavior: Behavioral I2n predictivity score: I2n is a metric that mainly measures the model's performance in predicting biological brain behavior. This can be achieved by comparing the differences between the model's output and actual behavioral data, such as calculating mean square error (MSE) or correlation.

Keywords: ANN, Feedforward, Recurrent

  1. The relationship between such very deep architectures and the ventral visual pathway is incomplete in at least two ways:

    • Current state-of-the-art ANNs appear to be too complex, compared with the relatively shallow cortical hierarchy.
    • Not complex enough in that they lack recurrent and skip connections and the resulting neural response dynamics that are commonplace in the ventral visual stream.

  2. COR: core object recognition = the ability to rapidly (<200 ms viewing duration) discriminate a given visual object (e.g., a car, top row) from all other possible visual objects (e.g., bottom row) without any object-specific or location-specific pre-cuing.

  3. Model Criteria: (The model's purpose)

    • Predictive, Internally Mappable. Similarities to Brain-structure.

    • Compact. Simplicity.

    • Computable: Specify output details. ??

    • Few layers
    • Single canonical circuitry. Connections between layers are the same.
    • Recurrent. Besides, responses overtime.

  4. CORnet Families:

    • CORnet-Z : A single convolution, followed by a ReLU nonlinearity and max pooling.

      • Lightweight version of AlexNet
      • Multiple fully-connected layers do not appear necessary

    • CORnet-R: simple recurrent model with biologically-plausible unrolling in time.

      • Recurrent dynamics that would propagate through the network in a biologically-valid manner

      Normally, (N4 -> N1; N1 -> N2); in a biological manner, (N4 -> N1, N4 + N1 -> N2) - An extra convolution in each model’s area - The state, the formal result is passed through another convolution, normalization, and nonlinearity.

    • CORnet-S:

      • Improvement on ResNet strucutre, following ResNet’s bottleneck block structure, the second convolution expands the number of channels fourfold while the last one decreases them back

docs.title: Motivations
docs.text:
• Sparse Interactions

    • The size of the kernel \(\ll\) The size of the input, we use small amount of kernels to detect some small features.
    • For a \(m\)-dimensional input and a \(n\)-dimensional output, a full-connection network have a \(m\times n\) matrix to store the parameters. However, by limiting the number of connections to \(k<m\), the matrix is reduced to \(k \times n\).

docs.title: Pooling
docs.text:
• The pooling function uses the overall statistical characteristics of the adjacent output at a certain position to replace the output of the network at that location.

  • When the input are slightly translated, the pooling function helps to make the expression of input invariant.

  • We care if a certain feature exists, but the specific position is unimportant.

  • Advantages:

  • Because the pooling integrates the feedback of all neighbors, it makes it possible that the pooling unit is smaller than the detection unit. We can use the integrated pooling area.

      from scipy import io
import os
import shutil
def move_valimg(val_dir='./val', devkit_dir='./ILSVRC2012_devkit_t12'):
"""
    move valimg to correspongding folders.
    val_id(start from 1) -> ILSVRC_ID(start from 1) -> WIND
    organize like:
    /val
    /n01440764
        images
    /n01443537
        images
        .....
    """
# load synset, val ground truth and val images list
synset = io.loadmat(os.path.join(devkit_dir, 'data', 'meta.mat'))
ground_truth = open(os.path.join(devkit_dir, 'data', 'ILSVRC2012_validation_ground_truth.txt'))
lines = ground_truth.readlines()
labels = [int(line[:-1]) for line in lines]
root, _, filenames = next(os.walk(val_dir))
for filename in filenames:
# val image name -> ILSVRC ID -> WIND
val_id = int(filename.split('.')[0].split('_')[-1])
ILSVRC_ID = labels[val_id-1]
WIND = synset['synsets'][ILSVRC_ID-1][0][1][0]
print("val_id:%d, ILSVRC_ID:%d, WIND:%s" % (val_id, ILSVRC_ID, WIND))
# move val images
output_dir = os.path.join(root, WIND)
if os.path.isdir(output_dir):
pass
else:
os.mkdir(output_dir)
shutil.move(os.path.join(root, filename), os.path.join(output_dir, filename))
if __name__ == '__main__':
move_valimg()
